questions.text: A 70-year-old woman, gravida 5, para 5, comes to the physician for the evaluation of sensation of vaginal fullness for the last six months. During this period, she has had lower back and pelvic pain that is worse with prolonged standing or walking. The patient underwent a hysterectomy at the age of 35 years because of severe dysmenorrhea. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypercholesterolemia. Medications include metformin and atorvastatin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination elicits a feeling of pressure on the perineum. Pelvic floor muscle and anal sphincter tone are decreased. Pelvic examination shows protrusion of the posterior vaginal wall with Valsalva maneuver and transparent, thick fluid at the vaginal introitus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although a large Bartholin gland cyst can cause pelvic pain which worsens on walking, a pelvic examination would show a unilateral, soft, fluctuant mass in the lower vestibular area. Moreover, a Bartholin gland cyst is uncommon in this patient's age group (more common in young women).

B) INCORRECT:

The decrease in estrogen levels in postmenopausal women (or those who have undergone hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy) can cause atrophic vaginitis. Although atrophic vaginitis can occasionally manifest with vaginal discharge, this patient's other clinical features (feeling of pressure on the perineum, decreased tone of pelvic floor muscle and anal sphincter, protrusion of the posterior vaginal wall) are inconsistent with this diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Although patients with infectious vulvovaginitis may also present with pelvic pain and vaginal discharge, the pelvic examination findings of posterior vaginal wall protrusion and lax sphincter in this patient are characteristic of another condition. In addition, the vaginal discharge of infectious vulvovaginitis is often purulent (e.g., in gonorrhea, chlamydia) and/or foul-smelling (e.g., bacterial vaginosis, trichomoniasis).

D) CORRECT:

Pelvic pressure and/or pain, which worsens on standing or walking, in the presence of posterior vaginal wall protrusion and lax sphincter tone on pelvic examination, is diagnostic of enterocele. This condition also causes increased vaginal discharge. Posterior vaginal wall prolapse can either be an enterocele (upper 1/3rd of the posterior vaginal wall) or rectocele (middle 1/3rd of the posterior vaginal wall). Both can occur concurrently.

E) INCORRECT:

Although vaginal cancer is more common in women > 60 years of age and can manifest with pelvic discomfort and vaginal discharge, it does not cause a prolapse of the posterior vaginal wall, as seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a condition that typically affects elderly women. Risk factors include multiparity, postmenopausal status, and prior pelvic surgery.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman comes to the physician because of several years of recurrent pelvic pain and constipation. She has increased fecal urgency and a sensation of incomplete evacuation following defecation. She has had no problems associated with urination. Her last menstrual period was 6 years ago. She has had three uncomplicated vaginal deliveries. Physical examination shows normal external genitalia. Speculum examination of the vagina and the cervix shows bulging of the posterior vaginal wall during Valsalva maneuver. Weakness of which of the following structures is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The pubocervical fascia, which is located between the cervix and the pubic bone area, forms part of the anterior vaginal wall. Weakness of this fascia results in a loss of support of the urethra and/or bladder, leading to cystocele and/or urethrocele. Patients typically present with urinary symptoms such as urgency, hesitation, incomplete emptying, and urinary incontinence, none of which is seen here. In addition, fecal urgency and a feeling of incomplete evacuation would not be expected. Moreover, anterior rather than posterior bulging of the vaginal wall would be expected during Valsalva maneuver.

B) CORRECT:

The rectovaginal fascia is part of the fibromuscular structure of the perianal body, and it separates the vagina and the rectum. Acquired weakness of the rectovaginal fascia, e.g., due to multiple vaginal deliveries or low estrogen levels during menopause, can cause herniation of the posterior vaginal wall, which is associated with protrusion of the rectum into the vaginal canal (i.e. rectocele), which can become visible during Valsalva maneuver. Typical symptoms of rectocele include increased fecal urgency and a sensation of incomplete evacuation following defecation. Patients with large rectoceles may report needing to insert their fingers into the vagina to press against the rectovaginal fascia, thereby facilitating the emptying of stool.

First-line therapy consists of conservative strategies, such as Kegel exercises, weight loss, a high-fiber diet, and vaginal pessaries.

C) INCORRECT:

The uterosacral ligament travels from the uterus to the anterior wall of the sacrum and fixes the upper vagina and uterus in place. Weakness of the uterosacral ligament can lead to uterine procidentia. This type of herniation can cause symptoms similar to those seen in this patient. However, uterine procidentia typically manifests with other symptoms as well, including a bulging vaginal mass, urinary incontinence, and vaginal bleeding, none of which is seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

The external anal sphincter can be compromised by perineal tearing during traumatic vaginal births. However, weakness of the external anal sphincter would cause fecal incontinence (i.e., involuntary loss of feces) rather than pelvic pain and constipation. Moreover, this patient has no history of complicated vaginal deliveries.

E) INCORRECT:

The cardinal ligament connects the cervix to the lateral wall of the peritoneum, providing support to the upper vagina and cervix. This ligament can be injured during hysterectomy, but it would not be affected by multiple vaginal births. Moreover, weakness of the cardinal ligament would not result in rectocele, but rather cause uterine prolapse.

F) INCORRECT:

The bulbospongiosus muscle is part of the inferior aspect of the urogenital diaphragm. Weakness or injury to this muscle (e.g., during vaginal delivery) can cause stress incontinence. However, this patient does not have urinary symptoms. Instead, she has defecatory symptoms associated with rectocele.
questions.hint: In a multiparous, postmenopausal woman presenting with pelvic pain, constipation, and bulging of the posterior vaginal wall during Valsalva maneuver, rectocele is the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician for a 2-month history of urinary incontinence and a vaginal mass. She has a history of five full-term normal vaginal deliveries. She gave birth to a healthy newborn 2-months ago. Since then she has felt a sensation of vaginal fullness and a firm mass in the lower vagina. She has loss of urine when she coughs, sneezes, or exercises. Pelvic examination shows an irreducible pink globular mass protruding out of the vagina. A loss of integrity of which of the following ligaments is most likely involved in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The infundibulopelvic ligament attaches the ovary to the lateral pelvic wall and contains both the vasculature and nervous/lymphatic supply of the ovary. This ligament does not provide substantial mechanical support to the uterus, so its loss of integrity would not lead to uterine prolapse.

B) CORRECT:

The uterosacral ligaments provide mechanical support to the uterus by connecting the cervix to the sacrum and lateral pelvis. These ligaments play a vital role in the prevention of uterine prolapse. The uterosacral ligaments also provide mechanical support to the pelvic floor as a whole and so play a role in the pathogenesis of the broader group of disorders comprised by pelvic organ prolapse. Important risk factors for uterine prolapse include age, high body mass index (BMI), multiparity, and obstetric conditions resulting from excessive stretching and tearing. Uterosacral ligament suspension (USLS) is a corrective procedure that involves stitching the uterosacral ligaments to the apex of the vagina, thereby restoring normal support to the top of the vagina.
Image Description:

The uterus is connected to the pelvic walls by ligaments and peritoneal folds. These structures provide support and allow for flexible movement of the uterus between the urinary bladder and the rectum, especially during pregnancy.

- The round ligament extends from the lateral horn of the uterus to the lateral pelvic wall and via the inguinal canal to the labia majora.
- The largest ligament is the broad ligament of the uterus, a peritoneal fold that connects the uterus to the lateral pelvic wall. The broad ligament can be divided into the mesosalpinx, the mesovarium, and the mesometrium.
- The ovaries are suspended from the uterus by the ovarian ligament and from the lateral pelvic wall by the suspensory (infundibulopelvic) ligament of the ovary.
- The cardinal ligament encloses the uterine artery and vein and connects the cervix with the lateral pelvic wall.
- The uterosacral ligament connects the cervix to the sacrum.

C) INCORRECT:

The cardinal ligaments of the uterus arise from the side of the cervix and the lateral fornix of the vagina. This ligament attaches the cervix and uterus to the lateral walls of the pelvis (at the level of the ischial spines). Although this ligament helps maintain the uterus in its position, it is not a major contributing factor to the mechanical support of the uterus. Therefore, the loss of integrity of this ligament would not lead to uterine prolapse.

The cardinal ligaments carry the uterine artery and vein, which constitute the main blood supply of the uterus. Due to their proximity to the ureters, the cardinal ligaments are of clinical significance in uterine surgeries that require ligation of the uterine vessels (e.g., a hysterectomy) as ureteral damage may occur.

D) INCORRECT:

The broad ligament of the uterus is a drape-like fold of peritoneum that serves as a mesentery and connects the uterus to the walls and floor of the pelvis. Although this ligament helps maintain the uterus in its position, it is not a major contributing factor to the mechanical support of the uterus. Therefore, the loss of integrity of this ligament would not lead to uterine prolapse.

E) INCORRECT:

The round ligament of uterus keeps the uterus anteverted (tilted forward) and anteflexed (bent forward) during pregnancy. The round ligament does not provide mechanical support to the uterus. Therefore, the loss of integrity to this ligament would not be the cause of this patient's symptoms.
Image Description:

The terms flexion and version are used to describe the position of the uterus.

Flexion refers to the angle between the axis of the uterine body (blue line) and the axis of the cervix (yellow line).
Version refers to the angle between the axis of the cervix and the axis of the vagina (green line).

The uterus is usually anteflexed by approx. 100 (AF) and anteverted by approx. 90 (AV), depending on how full the bladder is.
questions.hint: The stress incontinence and presence of a vaginal mass in a multiparous patient are consistent with uterine prolapse.

questions.text: A 79-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of difficulty starting urination and a vague sensation of fullness in the pelvis. Pelvic speculum examination in the lithotomy position shows a pink structure at the vaginal introitus that protrudes from the anterior vaginal wall when the patient is asked to cough. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A uterine prolapse, which is most common in elderly women, can cause urinary hesitancy and a sensation of pelvic fullness. However, this condition does not manifest with a structure at the vaginal introitus that protrudes from the anterior vaginal wall. Instead, a pelvic examination would show a descent of the uterus into the vagina and, in severe cases, through the vaginal introitus.
Image Description:

The cervix can be seen visibly protruding out of the vaginal introitus of this older postmenopausal patient. Note that the labia are thin and atrophic, a normal postmenopausal change.

B) INCORRECT:

Vaginal rhabdomyosarcoma is a malignant type of vaginal cancer that most commonly affects girls < 8 years of age; it is an unlikely diagnosis in this 79-year-old woman. In addition, this cancer does not typically cause urinary hesitancy or a sensation of pelvic fullness. Its classic appearance is a polypoid mass that resembles a bunch of grapes protruding through the vagina, not a structure at the vaginal introitus that protrudes from the anterior vaginal wall.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has a cystocele, a type of pelvic organ prolapse characterized by protrusion of the bladder behind the anterior vaginal wall and into the vaginal introitus. Cystoceles often prolapse further with maneuvers that increase intra-abdominal pressure (e.g., coughing). In addition, cystoceles typically cause urinary hesitancy and a sensation of pelvic fullness, as seen in this patient. Risk factors for cystocele include multiparity, low estrogen levels (e.g., after menopause), previous pelvic surgery (e.g., hysterectomy), and conditions that increase intraabdominal pressure (e.g., obesity). Conservative treatment options include vaginal pessaries, weight loss, and Kegel exercises; surgery can be used if the patient declines conservative treatment or if it fails.
Image Description:

Apical compartment prolapse (uterine prolapse, vaginal vault prolapse): herniated vaginal apex (uterus and cervix, cervix alone, or vaginal vault) into the lower vagina, hymen, or beyond the vaginal introitus

Posterior compartment prolapse: herniated posterior vaginal segment, often associated with rectocele (descent of the rectum) or enterocele (herniated section of the intestines)

Anterior compartment prolapse: herniated anterior vaginal wall, which is often associated with a cystocele (descent of the bladder) or urethrocele (descent of the urethra)

D) INCORRECT:

A rectocele, which is most common in elderly women, can cause a sensation of pelvic fullness. However, it does not typically cause urinary hesitancy. Further common symptoms of rectocele include constipation, sexual dysfunction, and fecal incontinence, none of which are seen in this patient. Moreover, rectoceles protrude from the posterior vaginal wall and into the vaginal introitus, not from the anterior vaginal wall.

E) INCORRECT:

Uterine leiomyomata (fibroids) can cause urinary hesitancy and a sensation of pelvic fullness. However, they do not manifest as a structure at the vaginal introitus that protrudes from the anterior vaginal wall. Instead, pelvic bimanual examination typically shows an enlarged, firm, and irregularly-shaped uterus. In addition, this patient does not have other typical findings of fibroids, including hypermenorrhea, menorrhagia, and dysmenorrhea. Moreover, fibroids typically develop in women of reproductive age and are less likely to be seen in postmenopausal women.
questions.hint: This patient's condition is caused by weakness of the pubocervical fascia.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of intermittent urinary incontinence. She loses small amounts of urine after voiding but is otherwise continent. She also reports occasional discomfort when voiding and during sexual intercourse. She does not have abdominal pain, increased urinary frequency, or urgency. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals with normal flow. Her last menstrual period was 12 days ago. She has no history of serious illness. She underwent a bilateral salpingectomy after her last pregnancy. She is sexually active with her husband and does not use condoms. She has three children who were delivered vaginally without complication. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a soft, tender, 2 x 2-cm mass in the anterior vaginal wall. There is no cervical motion tenderness. Urinalysis shows no abnormalities. Ultrasonography of the bladder shows a postvoid residual volume of 15 mL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A Bartholin gland cyst can result in mild dyspareunia and a palpable, tender mass on pelvic examination. However, these cysts are not typically associated with urinary incontinence or dysuria. Moreover, they develop at the posterior vaginal introitus, not the anterior vaginal wall.

B) INCORRECT:

Anterior vaginal wall prolapse (e.g., due to a cystocele or urethrocele) can manifest with urinary incontinence and an anterior vaginal wall mass and is associated with multiparity and prior pelvic surgery. However, this condition is typically nontender and causes stress urinary incontinence, not postvoid incontinence. In addition, anterior vaginal wall prolapse also typically causes a sensation of pelvic fullness, urinary frequency, and urgency, none of which is seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

A paraurethral gland cyst can cause dysuria, dyspareunia, and urinary incontinence. However, these cysts typically result in overflow incontinence, not postvoid incontinence. Moreover, pelvic examination typically shows masses located just lateral to the external urethral meatus rather than in the anterior vaginal wall.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has a urethral diverticulum, which classically manifests with the triad of urinary incontinence (in particular, postvoid dripping), dysuria, and dyspareunia. Urethral diverticula can sometimes be identified on pelvic examination as a usually tender anterior vaginal wall mass. The pathogenesis is poorly understood, but urethral diverticula are usually acquired rather than congenital. Risk factors include a history of multiple vaginal deliveries, prior gynecologic surgery, recurrent infection of the periurethral glands, and pelvic trauma that involves the vagina, bladder, and/or urethra.

E) INCORRECT:

A vesicovaginal fistula can cause urinary incontinence and is associated with prior pelvic surgery. However, this condition typically results in continuous leakage of urine (not postvoid incontinence) and a history of recurrent urinary tract infections. In addition, a vesicovaginal fistula does not cause a tender anterior vaginal wall mass.
Image Description:

Urogenital fistulas are abnormal connections between the vagina and the urogenital system (e.g., vesicovaginal fistula). Urogenital fistulas can manifest with continuous urinary leakage from the vagina.
questions.hint: Although vaginal delivery has been associated with an increased risk for developing this condition, it can also develop in nulliparous women.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 3, comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of voiding difficulties and pelvic discomfort. She works as a cashier but has been taking shorter shifts recently because her symptoms worsen after long periods of standing. She underwent open uterine myomectomy 20 years ago. There is no other personal or family history of serious illness. Her last menstrual period was 12 years ago. She has smoked one half-pack of cigarettes daily for 28 years but does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Her temperature is 36.8C (98.2F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg; BMI is 30 kg/m2. Pelvic examination shows a bulging mass from the vaginal introitus that protrudes more when the patient coughs. There is no urinary leakage upon straining. Pelvic ultrasonography shows a postvoid residual urine volume of 65 mL. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A history of pregnancy is the strongest risk factor for pelvic organ prolapse (POP) and is estimated to account for 75% of cases. The risk increases in multiparous women. POP is caused by weakness of the pelvic floor muscles (levator ani) and ligamentous supportive structure of the uterus and vagina. During childbirth, injury to the levator ani, ligaments, and/or local nerves (e.g., the pudendal nerve) can result in weakening of the pelvic floor, predisposing to POP.

B) INCORRECT:

Advancing age is associated with a progressive increase in the rate of pelvic organ prolapse (POP) because age-related changes (e.g., connective tissue degeneration, muscle weakness) result in weakness of the pelvic floor. Age is not, however, the greatest risk factor for POP.

C) INCORRECT:

Although obesity increases the risk for pelvic organ prolapse because of an increase in intraabdominal pressure, which strains the pelvic floor, it is not the greatest risk factor for this condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Although uterine surgery can result in injury to pelvic support structures and increase the risk for pelvic organ collapse, it is not the greatest risk factor for this condition. In addition, this patient underwent a uterine myomectomy, in which the risk of pelvic floor injury is relatively low compared to hysterectomy.

E) INCORRECT:

Menopause, which results in decreased estrogen levels, is associated with pelvic organ prolapse (POP). Low estrogen levels can contribute to a decrease in the collagen composition of the ligamentous supportive structure of the uterus and vagina, resulting in weakening of the pelvic floor. Menopause is not, however, the greatest risk factor for POP.
questions.hint: This patient's voiding difficulties, pelvic discomfort that worsens with prolonged standing, bulging vaginal mass that protrudes with straining, and increased postvoid residual urine volume are consistent with uterine prolapse.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 3, comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well besides a vague sensation of vaginal fullness for the last 5 months. Upon questioning, she also reports occasional mild lower back pain that worsens with prolonged standing or lifting. She does not have urinary or fecal incontinence. Ten years ago, she underwent a mastectomy for intraductal carcinoma of the right breast and has been cancer-free since then. All of her children were delivered vaginally without complications. Her last menstrual period was 3 years ago. She is sexually active with her husband only. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 85 kg (188 lb); BMI is 30 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination during Valsalva maneuver shows visible protrusion of the cervix proximal to the level of the hymen into the vagina. There is no urinary leakage upon straining. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hysterectomy, typically performed with concomitant transvaginal apical suspension, is a treatment option for POP with severe symptoms (e.g., urinary or defecatory dysfunction) and/or after unsuccessful first-line treatment of mild POP. This patient is only mildly symptomatic and has not yet received any treatment for her uterine prolapse. Therefore, a different intervention is more appropriate at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical estrogen is the first-line treatment option for moderate to severe atrophic vaginitis, which commonly occurs in menopause and may be concomitant to POP. Atrophic vaginitis typically manifests with vaginal soreness, dyspareunia, and vaginal discharge, none of which are seen in this patient. Topical estrogen is not indicated in patients with POP who do not have concomitant atrophic vaginitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and observation without treatment are indicated for patients with asymptomatic pelvic organ prolapse. This patient has a sensation of vaginal fullness and mild lower back pain due to uterine prolapse, which can be improved through treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Colporrhaphy is a highly effective treatment option for some types of POP, such as cystocele and rectocele, both of which can manifest with vaginal fullness and back pain. However, cystocele and rectocele are typically characterized by urinary and defecatory dysfunction, respectively, neither of which are seen here. This patient's clinical and physical examination findings are consistent with uterine prolapse, for which colporrhaphy is not indicated.

E) CORRECT:

Conservative treatment is the best initial step for managing patients with mildly symptomatic POP in the absence of urinary or defecatory dysfunction. The most commonly used conservative methods include vaginal pessaries and pelvic floor muscle training (e.g., Kegel exercises). Patients should also be advised on lifestyle modifications that help prevent the progression of POP through the reduction of intraabdominal pressure, such as weight loss, smoking cessation (to prevent chronic cough), and constipation treatment (to prevent straining). If the symptoms of POP persist or worsen despite conservative management, surgical treatment is indicated. Asymptomatic POP requires no treatment.
questions.hint: Vaginal fullness, lower back pain associated with prolonged standing, and protrusion of the cervix during Valsalva maneuver suggest uterine prolapse, a type of pelvic organ prolapse (POP). Multiple vaginal deliveries and obesity are risk factors for this condition.

questions.text:
A 61-year-old sexually active woman with no known medical problems reports a progressively worsening pressure sensation in her vaginal area that started about 2 years ago. Her vital signs are normal.
Her external genitalia appear normal with no masses or lesions. Her vaginal introitus is slightly enlarged; it exhibits a stage 2 anterior-wall prolapse and a stage 1 cervical prolapse. The vaginal wall is atrophic and dry. She indicates that she would prefer conservative management if it would be effective.
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Vaginal pessary in conjunction with estrogen cream

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Pelvic-organ prolapse involves the descent of one or more of the pelvic structures, such as the uterine cervix, vaginal apex, anterior vagina, posterior vagina, or peritoneum of the cul-de-sac. Risk factors for prolapse include a genetic predisposition, parity, menopause, advancing age, prior pelvic surgery, connective tissue disorders, and diseases characterized by increased intra-abdominal pressure.

A pessary is the only nonsurgical treatment specifically for pelvic-organ prolapse. A woman can be fitted for a pessary in a clinician's office, and 75% of urogynecologists use it as first-line therapy. Given the occurrence of vaginal atrophy in this patient, vaginal estrogen cream should be included in pessary use to avoid erosion of vaginal epithelium.

Key learning point: The most effective conservative treatment for pelvic-organ prolapse in a postmenopausal woman is use of a vaginal pessary.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral estrogen therapy is not effective for the management of pelvic-organ prolapse.

C) INCORRECT:

Surgical intervention would not be appropriate first-line treatment in a patient who prefers conservative management.

D) INCORRECT:

Restriction of certain beverages, such as alcohol or caffeinated drinks, can also minimize symptoms of urinary incontinence but has no proven benefit in the management of pelvic-organ prolapse.

E) INCORRECT:

Kegel exercises (pelvic-floor muscle rehabilitation) can also be offered as a nonsurgical approach, but these help mostly with specific symptoms such as urinary and fecal incontinence.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old gravida 4, para 4 woman presents with abdominal pain that started 3 weeks ago and that manifests as heaviness and pressure in her lower abdomen. She initially attributed the pain to constipation, as she has been straining to have bowel movements, but laxative use has not resolved the problem. About 2 weeks ago, she began to experience urinary urgency, and this week, she experienced pain during intercourse with her husband. She has no fevers, chills, nausea, vomiting, vaginal itching, or discharge. She is monogamous with her husband.
On physical examination, she is breathing comfortably and has a temperature of 37C, a blood pressure of 130/82 mm Hg, and a heart rate of 84 beats per minute. Her abdomen is soft and nondistended, but there is notable tenderness along the lower abdomen. There are no palpable inguinal lymph nodes.
Pelvic examination reveals no vulvar erythema or rashes. The cervix is noted to bulge into the vagina, and it becomes more prominent when the patient is asked to bear down during the Valsalva maneuver. Speculum examination reveals no vaginal discharge. On bimanual examination, there is no cervical motion tenderness, the uterus is retroflexed, and there is no adnexal tenderness.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Use of hysterectomy for uterine prolapse remains controversial, as hysterectomies do not correct loss of integrity of the cardinal-uterosacral ligament. Most studies have shown that women who undergo surgery for pelvic organ prolapse or urinary incontinence require revision procedures when prolapse recurs. Therefore, hysterectomy is not considered to be first-line therapy for uterine prolapse.

B) INCORRECT:

Although this patients report of abdominal pain and dyspareunia raises concern for a sexually transmitted infection or pelvic inflammatory disease, she is monogamous with her husband, and her pelvic examination did not reveal any signs of vaginal irritation, discharge, or cervical motion tenderness.

C) INCORRECT:

Pelvic floor exercises focus on training pelvic muscles, but their role in managing prolapse is unclear. No randomized controlled trials have confirmed that pelvic floor exercises are successful in treating uterine prolapse. Although recommending such exercises alone may be reasonable in mild cases of prolapse, these exercises would not be adequate as single therapy in this symptomatic patient.

D) CORRECT:

Pelvic organ prolapse is the descent of pelvic organs into the vaginal space. It can manifest with herniation of organs through the anterior or posterior vaginal wall (cystocele, rectocele, or enterocele) or with descent of the cervix and uterus into the vaginal canal (uterine prolapse). This patients presentation is consistent with uterine prolapse.

Patients with uterine prolapse often experience some combination of abdominal pressure or heaviness, changes in urination (increased frequency, urgency, or feeling of incomplete emptying), changes in stool (increased constipation and straining), and dyspareunia. Uterine prolapse is caused by weakening of support ligaments and results in herniation of the uterus into the vagina. Important risk factors include multiparity, BMI 25, advanced age, and less commonly, connective tissue disease.

Vaginal pessaries are considered to be first-line therapy for uterine prolapse. Pessaries typically provide immediate relief, particularly from stress or urge incontinence. Notably, pessaries do not reverse uterine prolapse, but they can reduce symptoms and prevent progression. Potential complications include vaginal irritation, discharge, and bleeding.

Key learning point: First-line therapy for uterine prolapse consists of a vaginal pessary.

E) INCORRECT:

Systemic estrogen can be used in postmenopausal women for relief of vasomotor symptoms of menopause, but it does not have a role in preventing or managing uterine prolapse. Topical estrogen is sometimes used together with a vaginal pessary to avoid vaginal erosion.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman with a history of four vaginal births reports having rectal discomfort and worsening constipation for the past 3 weeks. She describes the discomfort as pressure and reports straining during bowel movements. She has had constipation for the past 6 months, but the symptoms have worsened during the past 3 weeks. She takes stool softeners twice daily without relief. She eats a well-balanced diet with fiber and drinks at least six glasses of water per day. She reports no fevers, chills, unintentional weight loss, fatigue, or abdominal pain. She has had no dysuria or changes in urine output.
On physical examination, she is afebrile, has a blood pressure of 124/85 mm Hg and a heart rate of 87 beats per minute, and is breathing ambient air comfortably. Her BMI is 31.5. Her abdomen is soft, nontender, and nondistended. Visual examination of the vagina reveals normal mucosa but bulging of the posterior vaginal wall, which increases in size with the Valsalva maneuver. On rectal examination, anal sphincter tone is normal, and the examining finger is noted to enter the vaginal bulge.
What is the primary risk factor for this patients condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A history of stool-softener use is not associated with rectoceles or pelvic organ prolapse.

B) INCORRECT:

Increasing age is a known risk factor for rectoceles but another factor increases risk to a greater extent.

C) INCORRECT:

Obesity is a known risk factor for rectoceles but another factor increases risk to a greater extent.

D) CORRECT:

This patients rectal pressure and constipation are most likely caused by a rectocele, as evidenced by the finding of a posterior vaginal bulge that represents the anterior rectal wall on rectovaginal examination. Rectoceles, which are protrusions of the rectal wall into the vagina (shown below), vary in size and symptoms. Those <2 cm are usually asymptomatic, whereas those >4 cm are associated with prolapse and difficulty defecating. Rectoceles can be treated with training of the pelvic floor muscles or, if symptoms are progressive, surgical repair.

The main risk factor for rectoceles is multiparity, particularly vaginal childbirth, which can damage pelvic muscles and nerves, leading to weakness of the posterior vaginal wall and eventual prolapse. More than 75% of cases of pelvic organ prolapse are attributable to parity. Other risk factors include increasing age, obesity, constipation, and a history of hysterectomy, although these do not increase risk to the same extent as multiparity.

Key learning point: The primary risk factor for rectoceles is multiple vaginal deliveries.
Image Description:

Apical compartment prolapse (uterine prolapse, vaginal vault prolapse): herniated vaginal apex (uterus and cervix, cervix alone, or vaginal vault) into the lower vagina, hymen, or beyond the vaginal introitus

Posterior compartment prolapse: herniated posterior vaginal segment, often associated with rectocele (descent of the rectum) or enterocele (herniated section of the intestines)

Anterior compartment prolapse: herniated anterior vaginal wall, which is often associated with a cystocele (descent of the bladder) or urethrocele (descent of the urethra)

E) INCORRECT:

Chronic constipation is a known risk factor for rectoceles but another factor increases risk to a greater extent.

questions.text: A 79-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 1-month history of difficulty starting urination and a vague sensation of fullness in the pelvis. Pelvic speculum examination in the lithotomy position shows a pink structure at the vaginal introitus that protrudes from the anterior vaginal wall when the patient is asked to cough. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A uterine prolapse, which is most common in elderly women, can cause urinary hesitancy and a sensation of pelvic fullness. However, this condition does not manifest with a structure at the vaginal introitus that protrudes from the anterior vaginal wall. Instead, a pelvic examination would show a descent of the uterus into the vagina and, in severe cases, through the vaginal introitus.
Image Description:

The cervix can be seen visibly protruding out of the vaginal introitus of this older postmenopausal patient. Note that the labia are thin and atrophic, a normal postmenopausal change.

B) INCORRECT:

Vaginal rhabdomyosarcoma is a malignant type of vaginal cancer that most commonly affects girls < 8 years of age; it is an unlikely diagnosis in this 79-year-old woman. In addition, this cancer does not typically cause urinary hesitancy or a sensation of pelvic fullness. Its classic appearance is a polypoid mass that resembles a bunch of grapes protruding through the vagina, not a structure at the vaginal introitus that protrudes from the anterior vaginal wall.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has a cystocele, a type of pelvic organ prolapse characterized by protrusion of the bladder behind the anterior vaginal wall and into the vaginal introitus. Cystoceles often prolapse further with maneuvers that increase intra-abdominal pressure (e.g., coughing). In addition, cystoceles typically cause urinary hesitancy and a sensation of pelvic fullness, as seen in this patient. Risk factors for cystocele include multiparity, low estrogen levels (e.g., after menopause), previous pelvic surgery (e.g., hysterectomy), and conditions that increase intraabdominal pressure (e.g., obesity). Conservative treatment options include vaginal pessaries, weight loss, and Kegel exercises; surgery can be used if the patient declines conservative treatment or if it fails.
Image Description:

Apical compartment prolapse (uterine prolapse, vaginal vault prolapse): herniated vaginal apex (uterus and cervix, cervix alone, or vaginal vault) into the lower vagina, hymen, or beyond the vaginal introitus

Posterior compartment prolapse: herniated posterior vaginal segment, often associated with rectocele (descent of the rectum) or enterocele (herniated section of the intestines)

Anterior compartment prolapse: herniated anterior vaginal wall, which is often associated with a cystocele (descent of the bladder) or urethrocele (descent of the urethra)

D) INCORRECT:

A rectocele, which is most common in elderly women, can cause a sensation of pelvic fullness. However, it does not typically cause urinary hesitancy. Further common symptoms of rectocele include constipation, sexual dysfunction, and fecal incontinence, none of which are seen in this patient. Moreover, rectoceles protrude from the posterior vaginal wall and into the vaginal introitus, not from the anterior vaginal wall.

E) INCORRECT:

Fibroids can cause urinary hesitancy and a sensation of pelvic fullness. However, they do not manifest as a structure at the vaginal introitus that protrudes from the anterior vaginal wall. Instead, pelvic bimanual examination typically shows an enlarged, firm, and irregularly-shaped uterus. In addition, this patient does not have other typical findings of fibroids, including heavy menstrual bleeding and dysmenorrhea. Moreover, fibroids typically develop in women of reproductive age and are less likely to be seen in postmenopausal women.
questions.hint: This patient's condition is caused by weakness of the pubocervical fascia.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 3, comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well besides a vague sensation of vaginal fullness for the last 5 months. She also reports occasional mild lower back pain that worsens with prolonged standing or lifting. She does not have urinary or fecal incontinence. All of her children were delivered vaginally without complications. Her last menstrual period was 3 years ago. Body mass index is 30 kg/m2. Pelvic examination during Valsalva maneuver shows visible protrusion of the cervix proximal to the level of the hymen into the vagina. There is no urinary leakage upon straining. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hysterectomy, typically performed with concomitant transvaginal apical suspension, is a treatment option for POP with severe symptoms (e.g., urinary or defecatory dysfunction) and/or after unsuccessful first-line treatment of mild POP. This patient is only mildly symptomatic and has not yet received any treatment for her uterine prolapse. Therefore, a different intervention is more appropriate at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical estrogen is the first-line treatment option for moderate to severe atrophic vaginitis, which commonly occurs in menopause and may be concomitant to POP. Atrophic vaginitis typically manifests with vaginal soreness, dyspareunia, and vaginal discharge, none of which are seen in this patient. Topical estrogen is not indicated in patients with POP who do not have concomitant atrophic vaginitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and observation without treatment are indicated for patients with asymptomatic pelvic organ prolapse. This patient has a sensation of vaginal fullness and mild lower back pain due to uterine prolapse, which can be improved through treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Colporrhaphy is a highly effective treatment option for some types of POP, such as cystocele and rectocele, both of which can manifest with vaginal fullness and back pain. However, cystocele and rectocele are typically characterized by urinary and defecatory dysfunction, respectively, neither of which are seen here. This patient's clinical and physical examination findings are consistent with uterine prolapse, for which colporrhaphy is not indicated.

E) CORRECT:

Conservative treatment is the best initial step for managing patients with mildly symptomatic POP in the absence of urinary or defecatory dysfunction. The most commonly used conservative methods include vaginal pessaries and pelvic floor muscle training (e.g., Kegel exercises). Patients should also be advised on lifestyle modifications that help prevent the progression of POP through the reduction of intraabdominal pressure, such as weight loss, smoking cessation (to prevent chronic cough), and constipation treatment (to prevent straining). If the symptoms of POP persist or worsen despite conservative management, surgical treatment is indicated. Asymptomatic POP requires no treatment.
questions.hint: Vaginal fullness, lower back pain associated with prolonged standing, and protrusion of the cervix during Valsalva maneuver suggest uterine prolapse, a type of pelvic organ prolapse (POP). Multiple vaginal deliveries and obesity are risk factors for this condition.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of four vaginal births reports having rectal discomfort and constipation. She describes the discomfort as pressure and reports straining during bowel movements. She has had constipation for the past 6 months, but the symptoms have worsened during the past 3 weeks. She takes stool softeners without relief. She reports no fevers, chills, unintentional weight loss, fatigue, or abdominal pain. Vital signs are within normal limits. Body mass index is 32 kg/m2. Her abdomen is soft, nontender, and nondistended. Examination of the vagina reveals normal mucosa but bulging of the posterior vaginal wall, which increases in size with the Valsalva maneuver. On rectal examination, anal sphincter tone is normal, and the examining finger is noted to enter the vaginal bulge. Which of the following is the primary risk factor for this patients condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A history of stool-softener use is not associated with rectoceles or pelvic organ prolapse.

B) INCORRECT:

Increasing age is a known risk factor for rectoceles but another factor increases risk to a greater extent.

C) INCORRECT:

Obesity is a known risk factor for rectoceles but another factor increases risk to a greater extent.

D) CORRECT:

This patients rectal pressure and constipation are most likely caused by a rectocele, as evidenced by the finding of a posterior vaginal bulge that represents the anterior rectal wall on rectovaginal examination. Rectoceles, which are protrusions of the rectal wall into the vagina, vary in size and symptoms. Those < 2 cm are usually asymptomatic, whereas those > 4 cm are associated with prolapse and difficulty defecating. Rectoceles can be treated with training of the pelvic floor muscles or, if symptoms are progressive, surgical repair.

The main risk factor for rectoceles is multiparity, particularly vaginal childbirth, which can damage pelvic muscles and nerves, leading to weakness of the posterior vaginal wall and eventual prolapse. More than 75% of cases of pelvic organ prolapse are attributable to parity. Other risk factors include increasing age, obesity, constipation, and a history of hysterectomy, although these do not increase risk to the same extent as multiparity.

Key learning point: The primary risk factor for rectoceles is multiple vaginal deliveries.
Image Description:

Apical compartment prolapse (uterine prolapse, vaginal vault prolapse): herniated vaginal apex (uterus and cervix, cervix alone, or vaginal vault) into the lower vagina, hymen, or beyond the vaginal introitus

Posterior compartment prolapse: herniated posterior vaginal segment, often associated with rectocele (descent of the rectum) or enterocele (herniated section of the intestines)

Anterior compartment prolapse: herniated anterior vaginal wall, which is often associated with a cystocele (descent of the bladder) or urethrocele (descent of the urethra)

E) INCORRECT:

Chronic constipation is a known risk factor for rectoceles but another factor increases risk to a greater extent.
questions.hint: In a multiparous woman presenting with rectal discomfort, constipation, and bulging of the posterior vaginal wall during Valsalva maneuver, rectocele is the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 4, presents with a 2-month history of voiding difficulties and pelvic discomfort. She works as a cashier but has been taking shorter shifts recently because her symptoms worsen after long periods of standing. She underwent open uterine myomectomy 20 years ago. Her last menstrual period was 12 years ago. She has smoked one half-pack of cigarettes daily for 28 years. Her temperature is 36.8C (98.2F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg; BMI is 30 kg/m2. Pelvic examination shows a bulging mass from the vaginal introitus that protrudes more when the patient coughs. There is no urinary leakage upon straining. Pelvic ultrasonography shows a postvoid residual urine volume of 65 mL. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A history of pregnancy is the strongest risk factor for pelvic organ prolapse (POP) and is estimated to account for 75% of cases. The risk increases in multiparous women. POP is caused by weakness of the pelvic floor muscles (levator ani) and ligamentous supportive structure of the uterus and vagina. During childbirth, injury to the levator ani, ligaments, and/or local nerves (e.g., the pudendal nerve) can result in weakening of the pelvic floor, predisposing to POP.

B) INCORRECT:

Advancing age is associated with a progressive increase in the rate of pelvic organ prolapse (POP) because age-related changes (e.g., connective tissue degeneration, muscle weakness) result in weakness of the pelvic floor. Age is not, however, the greatest risk factor for POP.

C) INCORRECT:

Although obesity increases the risk for pelvic organ prolapse because of an increase in intraabdominal pressure, which strains the pelvic floor, it is not the greatest risk factor for this condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Although uterine surgery can result in injury to pelvic support structures and increase the risk for pelvic organ collapse, it is not the greatest risk factor for this condition. In addition, this patient underwent a uterine myomectomy, in which the risk of pelvic floor injury is relatively low compared to hysterectomy.

E) INCORRECT:

Menopause, which results in decreased estrogen levels, is associated with pelvic organ prolapse (POP). Low estrogen levels can contribute to a decrease in the collagen composition of the ligamentous supportive structure of the uterus and vagina, resulting in weakening of the pelvic floor. Menopause is not, however, the greatest risk factor for POP.
questions.hint: This patient's voiding difficulties, pelvic discomfort that worsens with prolonged standing, bulging vaginal mass that protrudes with straining, and increased postvoid residual urine volume are consistent with uterine prolapse.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with a persistent sensation of bulging in the vagina that worsens when she stands or coughs. She also reports occasional stress urinary incontinence, difficulty initiating urination, and incomplete bladder emptying. She denies significant bowel changes and experiences only mild lower back discomfort. On pelvic examination, a protrusion is noted from the anterior vaginal wall.
Which of the following diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Enterocele involves herniation of peritoneal contents into the rectovaginal space, typically presenting as a bulge at the vaginal apex or posterior wall. The anterior vaginal wall bulge and urinary symptoms, such as stress incontinence, suggest bladder involvement rather than enterocele. The lack of significant bowel symptoms and the anatomical location of the protrusion do not align with enterocele.

B) CORRECT:

Cystocele manifests as the herniation of the bladder into the anterior vaginal wall due to weakening of the vesicovaginal fascia. It is common in postmenopausal women with a history of pelvic floor stress. Symptoms include a sensation of vaginal bulge, especially when standing or coughing, and urinary issues such as stress incontinence, difficulty initiating urination, and incomplete bladder emptying. These symptoms result from altered bladder positioning and disrupted support of the lower urinary tract. The anterior vaginal wall bulge observed during pelvic examination confirms the diagnosis.

Key learning point: A cystocele is characterized by anterior vaginal wall prolapse, leading to symptoms such as vaginal fullness, urinary incontinence, and incomplete bladder emptying.

C) INCORRECT:

Rectocele involves herniation of the rectum into the posterior vaginal wall, often causing bowel-related symptoms like difficulty with defecation. The anterior vaginal wall bulge and urinary symptoms, such as stress incontinence and voiding difficulties, align more with cystocele. The absence of significant bowel changes further reduces the likelihood of rectocele.

D) INCORRECT:

Uterine prolapse involves descent of the uterus, typically presenting with a bulge from the cervix or uterine fundus. The anterior vaginal wall protrusion and urinary symptoms, such as stress incontinence, indicate bladder involvement rather than uterine descent. The absence of cervical or uterine descent findings further argues against uterine prolapse.

questions.text:
A 61-year-old G3P3 woman presents to the clinic with a chronic sensation of pelvic heaviness and a bulge at the vaginal opening that becomes more noticeable when standing for prolonged periods. She reports occasional stress urinary incontinence and a feeling of incomplete bladder emptying. She has never undergone a detailed examination and is otherwise healthy. On visual inspection, a soft protrusion is noted at the introitus.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to evaluate her symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

MRI of the pelvis provides detailed views of pelvic anatomy and is useful in complex cases or when clinical examination is uncertain. However, in straightforward cases of suspected pelvic organ prolapse, a focused pelvic examination is sufficient for diagnosis and staging, making MRI unnecessary as an initial evaluation step.

B) INCORRECT:

Pelvic ultrasound is useful for evaluating intra-abdominal or pelvic pathologies, such as adnexal masses, but it is not necessary for initial evaluation of pelvic organ prolapse. The condition is best assessed through a physical examination, which provides real-time assessment of pelvic floor support and allows for accurate grading of prolapse severity.

C) INCORRECT:

Pelvic floor physical therapy is a treatment option for pelvic floor disorders, including mild prolapse and stress urinary incontinence. However, it is not appropriate as an initial evaluation step. A detailed pelvic examination is necessary to assess the degree of prolapse and determine the appropriate management strategy.

D) CORRECT:

A speculum-assisted pelvic examination is essential for evaluating suspected pelvic organ prolapse. It allows direct visualization of the vaginal walls, cervix, and pelvic structures, facilitating accurate characterization and grading of the prolapse using standardized systems like the Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification (POP-Q) system. This examination is crucial for assessing anatomical support and informing management decisions, especially in patients presenting with symptoms such as pelvic heaviness, a vaginal bulge, and urinary issues.

Key learning point: In cases of suspected pelvic organ prolapse, a speculum examination of the vagina is the most appropriate initial step to assess the extent and type of prolapse.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old woman presents with two years of progressively worsening pelvic pressure and a bulge inside her vagina that becomes more prominent toward the end of the day. She denies urinary incontinence. She has a history of three uncomplicated vaginal deliveries. On inspection, the vulva appears normal, and no obvious protrusion is seen at rest. A cursory pelvic exam reveals difficulty visualizing the cervix.
What is the most appropriate initial step to further evaluate her condition?

choices.text: Speculum examination of the vagina while the patient bears down

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Immediate surgical repair is premature without a comprehensive evaluation to determine the extent of prolapse and involvement of pelvic compartments. Surgical intervention is considered after confirming prolapse severity and exploring conservative management options, ensuring the intervention matches the patient's condition and symptoms.

B) CORRECT:

Dynamic pelvic evaluation is essential for assessing suspected pelvic organ prolapse. A speculum examination while the patient bears down increases intra-abdominal pressure, accentuating the descent of pelvic structures like the uterine cervix. This maneuver provides a direct view of the vaginal canal and cervix, allowing for accurate assessment of prolapse degree and pattern. It serves as a first-line diagnostic tool by confirming structural weakness of pelvic support, often following obstetric trauma.

Key learning point: In cases of suspected pelvic organ prolapse, a speculum examination of the vagina is the most appropriate initial step to assess the presence and severity of the prolapse.

C) INCORRECT:

MRI provides high-resolution imaging of soft tissue anatomy and is valuable in complex cases, such as planning reconstructive surgery. However, pelvic organ prolapse is primarily diagnosed by a dynamic pelvic examination. MRI is excessive for initial evaluation, as its strengths lie in addressing ambiguous findings or preoperative planning, neither of which is indicated here.

D) INCORRECT:

Pelvic ultrasound is useful for assessing intra-abdominal and pelvic organ pathology, such as adnexal masses or uterine fibroids. However, it is limited in evaluating the functional support of pelvic organs. It does not effectively capture the dynamic descent of pelvic organs or provide a detailed evaluation of pelvic floor support structures, making it less suitable for initial prolapse evaluation.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old G4P4 woman presents with a vaginal bulge and chronic difficulty emptying her bowels for the past year. She frequently presses against the posterior vaginal wall to assist defecation and reports no urinary incontinence. She has tried stool softeners and pelvic floor exercises with minimal relief. Physical examination shows a prominent bulge of the posterior vaginal wall that increases with straining, with no significant anterior vaginal prolapse.
Which surgical procedure is most appropriate to address her primary problem?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A midurethral sling is used to treat stress urinary incontinence by supporting the mid-urethra. The patient does not report urinary incontinence, and her symptoms are related to a posterior vaginal wall defect, consistent with a rectocele. Therefore, a midurethral sling does not address her defecatory issues.

B) INCORRECT:

Anterior colporrhaphy addresses defects in the anterior vaginal wall, such as cystocele, where the bladder bulges into the vagina. The patient's symptoms and examination findings indicate a posterior vaginal wall defect, consistent with a rectocele, not an anterior compartment issue. The absence of urinary symptoms further suggests that the anterior structures are not involved.

C) INCORRECT:

LeFort colpocleisis is a vaginal obliterative procedure for advanced pelvic organ prolapse in patients who are no longer sexually active. It is more suitable for apical or multiple compartment prolapse. The patient's symptoms and examination findings indicate a posterior vaginal wall defect, consistent with a rectocele, which is better addressed by posterior colporrhaphy. Additionally, there is no indication that the patient wishes to forgo vaginal function.

D) CORRECT:

The patient's symptoms and examination findings are indicative of a rectocele, characterized by a defect in the posterior vaginal wall where the rectum protrudes into the vaginal cavity, causing defecatory dysfunction. The prominent bulge in the posterior vaginal wall that worsens with straining supports this diagnosis. Posterior colporrhaphy involves reconstructing and reinforcing the rectovaginal fascia to restore anatomical support and improve bowel emptying. This procedure is appropriate when conservative measures, such as pelvic floor exercises and stool softeners, have failed to relieve symptoms.

Key learning point: Posterior colporrhaphy is the appropriate surgical treatment for rectocele, which presents with symptoms of difficulty in defecation and the need for manual assistance to evacuate the bowels.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old woman presents with a one-year history of a dragging sensation in her pelvis that has gradually worsened. She reports a bulge protruding near the posterior vagina, more apparent after prolonged standing. She underwent a total hysterectomy 20 years ago. Physical examination reveals a distinct fullness in the upper posterior vaginal wall, which partially reduces on recumbency. She has no urinary complaints but occasional constipation.
Which of the following diagnoses best explains her presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cystocele involves the descent of the bladder into the anterior vaginal wall, not the posterior wall. It often presents with urinary symptoms, such as stress incontinence, which are absent in this patient. The fullness in the upper posterior vaginal wall and occasional constipation suggest posterior wall involvement, not cystocele.

B) INCORRECT:

Rectocele involves herniation of the anterior rectal wall into the vaginal lumen, typically affecting the mid to lower posterior vaginal wall. The patient's fullness is in the upper posterior vaginal wall, which is atypical for rectocele. Additionally, significant rectocele often causes defecatory issues, such as the need for manual splinting, which are not reported by this patient.

C) CORRECT:

Enterocele involves the herniation of peritoneal contents, often including small bowel loops, into the upper posterior vaginal fornix. It is common in women with a history of total hysterectomy due to weakened pelvic support structures. The patient's symptoms, including a dragging pelvic sensation and a bulge in the upper posterior vaginal wall that worsens with standing and reduces when recumbent, align with enterocele. Occasional constipation may result from pressure on the bowel, indicating involvement of small intestinal loops in the herniated tissue.

Key learning point: An enterocele, characterized by herniation of the small bowel into the upper posterior vaginal wall, can cause pelvic pressure and heaviness, and is a common cause of pelvic organ prolapse symptoms in postmenopausal women.

D) INCORRECT:

Uterine prolapse involves the descent of the uterus through the vaginal canal, identified by a protruding cervix. This patient had a total hysterectomy, eliminating the possibility of uterine prolapse. The bulge in the upper posterior vaginal wall suggests a different type of pelvic support failure, such as enterocele.

questions.text:
An 82-year-old woman presents to the Outpatient Clinic for a routine check-up. She has a history of chronic hypertension and mild osteoarthritis. She reports no new symptoms and remains active with daily tasks. External inspection reveals a prolapsed uterus at the introitus, consistent with uterine procidentia. She has no pelvic pain, minimal stress urinary leakage, and is averse to invasive procedures. Vital signs are stable.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management step at this point?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In elderly patients with uterine procidentia and minimal symptoms, a vaginal pessary is an appropriate management option. This nonsurgical device provides mechanical support to the prolapsed uterus, alleviating symptoms like stress urinary incontinence without the risks associated with surgery. It aligns with the patient's preference against invasive procedures and allows for outpatient management with periodic assessments to ensure proper fit and monitor for complications such as vaginal irritation.

Key learning point: In elderly patients with uterine procidentia who are asymptomatic and managing well, conservative management with a vaginal pessary is preferred over surgical options due to lower risk and invasiveness.

B) INCORRECT:

Immediate surgical correction is typically reserved for patients with significant prolapse symptoms or complications. This 82-year-old patient has minimal symptoms and is averse to invasive procedures. Surgical intervention carries higher perioperative risks in elderly patients, especially those with comorbidities like hypertension, making it less suitable in this context.

C) INCORRECT:

Sacrocolpopexy is a surgical procedure for significant prolapse symptoms. It is not ideal for this 82-year-old patient with minimal symptoms and an aversion to invasive procedures. The risks of major surgery outweigh the benefits when noninvasive options like a pessary are available.

D) INCORRECT:

Pelvic floor muscle exercises can help with mild prolapse or stress urinary incontinence but are insufficient for uterine procidentia, where structural support is compromised. In elderly patients, muscle tone loss limits the effectiveness of exercises alone, making mechanical support like a pessary more appropriate.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old G3P3 woman presents with a 3-month history of a sensation of fullness in her vagina and mild pelvic pressure that worsens with prolonged standing. She denies urinary complaints or bowel changes and states the issue does not significantly interfere with her daily activities. She is otherwise healthy. On pelvic examination, a stage II uterine prolapse is observed, with the cervix descending midway between the hymen and the vaginal introitus.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Surgical hysterectomy with pelvic floor reconstruction
Pelvic floor muscle training and continued observation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anterior colporrhaphy addresses anterior vaginal wall defects, such as cystocele, not uterine prolapse. This patient has stage II uterine prolapse with mild symptoms and no urinary complaints. Anterior colporrhaphy does not address the uterine descent and is not appropriate here.

B) INCORRECT:

LeFort colpocleisis is a vaginal obliterative procedure for advanced prolapse in patients no longer sexually active. This patient has mild symptoms and no indication of sexual inactivity. The procedure is irreversible and sacrifices future sexual activity, making it inappropriate for this scenario.

C) INCORRECT:

Surgical hysterectomy with pelvic floor reconstruction is reserved for advanced prolapse or failed conservative management. In stage II prolapse with mild symptoms, conservative measures like pelvic floor exercises are preferred. Surgery carries risks such as anesthesia complications and postoperative morbidity, which outweigh benefits when symptoms are minimal.

D) CORRECT:

In stage II pelvic organ prolapse with mild symptoms that do not significantly impact daily activities, conservative management is appropriate. Pelvic floor muscle training, such as Kegel exercises, strengthens the pelvic support muscles, potentially reducing symptoms and slowing prolapse progression. Continued observation allows for monitoring changes in symptom severity or prolapse grade, reserving invasive options for worsening symptoms or significant quality of life impact.

Key learning point: In cases of mild to moderate pelvic organ prolapse with minimal symptoms, conservative management with pelvic floor exercises, reassurance, and follow-up is often the first step.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old G3P3 woman presents with a 2-year history of pelvic pressure and a visible vaginal bulge. She has completed pelvic floor muscle training and used a vaginal pessary for 8 months, but her symptoms persist and interfere with daily activities. On examination, the uterus descends beyond the hymen upon straining. She desires a lasting solution.
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Pelvic floor exercises for 6 more months

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A different pessary type might help if fit or comfort were issues, but this patient has already used a pessary for 8 months without symptom relief. Her desire for a lasting solution and the persistence of symptoms suggest that switching pessaries would not provide the definitive correction needed.

B) INCORRECT:

Pelvic floor exercises are effective for mild prolapse but are unlikely to benefit this patient, who has already completed an adequate trial of conservative management without relief. The uterus descends beyond the hymen, indicating advanced prolapse, and the patient desires a lasting solution, making further exercises inappropriate.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has advanced pelvic organ prolapse, with the uterus descending beyond the hymen and persistent symptoms despite conservative management, including pelvic floor muscle training and pessary use. Surgical repair is indicated to restore pelvic support structures and correct the prolapse. Procedures may include posterior colporrhaphy or more comprehensive reconstructive techniques. The patient's age, multiparity, and significant symptom impact suggest that conservative measures are insufficient, and surgical intervention offers a lasting resolution by addressing the anatomical defect.

Key learning point: In cases of significant pelvic organ prolapse with persistent symptoms despite conservative management, counseling for surgical management is appropriate to provide a definitive solution and improve quality of life.

D) INCORRECT:

Local vaginal estrogen improves vaginal epithelium quality and reduces atrophic vaginitis symptoms but does not address the mechanical defect in pelvic support causing advanced prolapse. The patient's symptoms persist despite conservative measures, indicating that estrogen therapy alone is inadequate.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old G2P1 woman at 24 weeks gestation presents to the clinic with mild fullness in her vagina for the past 3 weeks. She denies any pain, urinary incontinence, or bleeding. Physical examination reveals a mild anterior vaginal wall bulge consistent with a first-degree cystocele. The remainder of the exam is normal, and both mother and fetus are stable. She expresses concern about management and future complications.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Reassure that no immediate intervention is required

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Surgical repair is reserved for severe or symptomatic pelvic organ prolapse. In pregnancy, surgery poses risks to both mother and fetus. Mild prolapse often improves postpartum, and conservative measures are preferred during pregnancy.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical estrogen is used in postmenopausal women for vaginal atrophy. In pregnancy, estrogen levels are already elevated, and the mild prolapse is due to pelvic support changes, not estrogen deficiency. Exogenous estrogen is unnecessary and potentially risky during pregnancy.

C) CORRECT:

Mild prolapse, such as a first-degree cystocele during pregnancy, is often due to increased relaxin levels and changes in connective tissue integrity. These changes facilitate childbirth and typically resolve postpartum. The absence of pain, urinary incontinence, or bleeding, along with stable maternal-fetal status, supports expectant management. In the absence of significant symptoms or progression, reassurance and conservative management are appropriate, with potential consideration for pelvic floor exercises postpartum.

Key learning point: In asymptomatic cases of vaginal prolapse during pregnancy, conservative management with reassurance is often the most appropriate approach, as many cases resolve postpartum without the need for immediate intervention.

D) INCORRECT:

A vaginal ring pessary is used for more advanced pelvic organ prolapse or significant symptoms like pelvic discomfort or urinary incontinence. This patient has a first-degree cystocele with minimal symptoms, making pessary insertion unnecessary.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman presents with four months of intermittent dysuria, post-void dribbling, and occasional painful intercourse. She denies fever or flank pain and has minimal urinary frequency. On pelvic examination, a small, tender mass is palpated along the anterior vaginal wall, and applying pressure over the mass occasionally expresses a small amount of fluid. Urinalysis is normal, and culture is negative. She is otherwise in good health.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Interstitial cystitis is characterized by chronic bladder pain, urgency, and frequency, without a distinct mass or fluid collection. The patient's minimal urinary frequency and the presence of a tender mass with fluid expression are inconsistent with interstitial cystitis, which involves diffuse bladder hypersensitivity.

B) INCORRECT:

Cystocele involves bladder prolapse into the anterior vaginal wall, common in older, multiparous women. It presents with a reducible mass accentuated by Valsalva maneuver and symptoms like urinary stress incontinence. The tender mass with fluid expression in this patient suggests a cystic lesion, not a cystocele.

C) INCORRECT:

Gartner duct cysts are remnants of the mesonephric ducts, typically located along the lateral vaginal walls. They are usually asymptomatic unless significantly enlarged. The anterior vaginal wall mass with fluid expression and associated symptoms in this patient are inconsistent with a Gartner duct cyst.

D) CORRECT:

Urethral diverticulum is a localized outpouching of the urethral lumen into periurethral tissues, often seen in women of reproductive age. It manifests with urinary symptoms such as dysuria and post-void dribbling due to urine stasis, and dyspareunia from mass effect or inflammation. Physical examination typically reveals a tender, compressible mass along the anterior vaginal wall, with fluid expression upon pressure. Normal urinalysis and culture findings highlight the need for imaging, such as MRI or transvaginal ultrasound, to confirm the diagnosis and guide management.

Key learning point: Urethral diverticulum can present with dribbling of urine, dyspareunia, and dysuria due to the presence of a pouch-like structure that can collect urine and become infected or inflamed.

questions.text: A 79-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 1-month history of difficulty initiating urination and a vague sensation of pelvic fullness. On pelvic speculum examination in the lithotomy position, you observe a pink structure at the vaginal introitus that protrudes from the anterior vaginal wall when she coughs. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vaginal rhabdomyosarcoma is a malignant type of vaginal cancer that most commonly affects girls < 8 years of age; it is an unlikely diagnosis in this 79-year-old woman. In addition, this cancer does not typically cause urinary hesitancy or a sensation of pelvic fullness. Its classic appearance is a polypoid mass that resembles a bunch of grapes protruding through the vagina, not a structure at the vaginal introitus that protrudes from the anterior vaginal wall.

B) INCORRECT:

A rectocele, which is most common in elderly women, can cause a sensation of pelvic fullness. However, it does not typically cause urinary hesitancy. Further common symptoms of rectocele include constipation, sexual dysfunction, and fecal incontinence, none of which are seen in this patient. Moreover, rectoceles protrude from the posterior vaginal wall and into the vaginal introitus, not from the anterior vaginal wall.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has a cystocele, a type of pelvic organ prolapse characterized by protrusion of the bladder behind the anterior vaginal wall and into the vaginal introitus. Cystoceles often prolapse further with maneuvers that increase intra-abdominal pressure (e.g., coughing). In addition, cystoceles typically cause urinary hesitancy and a sensation of pelvic fullness, as seen in this patient. Risk factors for cystocele include multiparity, low estrogen levels (e.g., after menopause), previous pelvic surgery (e.g., hysterectomy), and conditions that increase intraabdominal pressure (e.g., obesity). Conservative treatment options include vaginal pessaries, weight loss, and Kegel exercises; surgery can be used if the patient declines conservative treatment or if it fails.

Key learning point: A cystocele is the protrusion of the bladder through the anterior vaginal wall, often causing pelvic fullness and urinary symptoms, especially in postmenopausal women.
Image Description:

Apical compartment prolapse (uterine prolapse, vaginal vault prolapse): herniated vaginal apex (uterus and cervix, cervix alone, or vaginal vault) into the lower vagina, hymen, or beyond the vaginal introitus

Posterior compartment prolapse: herniated posterior vaginal segment, often associated with rectocele (descent of the rectum) or enterocele (herniated section of the intestines)

Anterior compartment prolapse: herniated anterior vaginal wall, which is often associated with a cystocele (descent of the bladder) or urethrocele (descent of the urethra)

D) INCORRECT:

A uterine prolapse, which is most common in elderly women, can cause urinary hesitancy and a sensation of pelvic fullness. However, this condition does not manifest with a structure at the vaginal introitus that protrudes from the anterior vaginal wall. Instead, a pelvic examination would show a descent of the uterus into the vagina and, in severe cases, through the vaginal introitus.

E) INCORRECT:

Fibroids can cause urinary hesitancy and a sensation of pelvic fullness. However, they do not manifest as a structure at the vaginal introitus that protrudes from the anterior vaginal wall. Instead, pelvic bimanual examination typically shows an enlarged, firm, and irregularly-shaped uterus. In addition, this patient does not have other typical findings of fibroids, including heavy menstrual bleeding and dysmenorrhea. Moreover, fibroids typically develop in women of reproductive age and are less likely to be seen in postmenopausal women.
questions.hint: This patient's condition is caused by weakness of the pubocervical fascia.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents with a 1-week history of pelvic pressure and difficulty urinating. She reports feeling like she cannot completely empty her bladder and has been straining to void. She has a history of four vaginal deliveries. On examination, tissue is visualized protruding from the vaginal introitus that becomes more prominent with straining. The most distal portion extends 3 cm below the hymenal plane. Postvoid residual volume is 400 mL. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pelvic floor muscle training is recommended for all patients with prolapse as part of conservative management, but this patient has acute urinary retention that requires immediate intervention.

B) INCORRECT:

Manual reduction may provide temporary relief but does not address the underlying prolapse or the acute urinary retention.

C) INCORRECT:

Vaginal pessary is appropriate definitive management for symptomatic prolapse, but pessary fitting requires specialized training and follow-up that is not typically available in the emergency department.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has stage 3 pelvic organ prolapse with significant urinary retention (postvoid residual > 400 mL). The immediate priority in the emergency department is relieving the urinary retention through catheterization, followed by outpatient gynecology referral for definitive management, which includes pessary fitting or surgical options.

E) INCORRECT:

Gynecologic consultation is appropriate for definitive management of pelvic organ prolapse, but immediate surgical consultation is not indicated in the emergency setting for uncomplicated prolapse.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old postmenopausal woman presents for routine follow-up. She has a history of three vaginal deliveries. She has no specific complaints and denies urinary incontinence, pelvic pain, or difficulty with bowel movements. She is otherwise active. Pelvic examination reveals a visible bulge of the anterior vaginal wall consistent with a mild prolapse.
What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vaginal pessaries are used for symptomatic relief in moderate to severe prolapse or when surgery is not an option. This patient has a mild, asymptomatic prolapse, making conservative management preferable to avoid unnecessary interventions and potential complications like vaginal irritation.

B) INCORRECT:

Surgical correction is reserved for moderate to severe prolapse with bothersome symptoms. This patient has a mild, asymptomatic prolapse, making her a candidate for conservative management. Surgery carries risks such as anesthesia complications and postoperative morbidity, which are not justified in this setting.

C) CORRECT:

In asymptomatic patients with mild vaginal wall prolapse, conservative management is appropriate. This patient lacks symptoms such as urinary incontinence, pelvic pain, or bowel dysfunction, supporting observation rather than intervention. Reassurance and routine follow-up, possibly including pelvic floor exercises, are recommended unless the prolapse progresses or symptoms develop. Topical estrogen therapy, while beneficial for vaginal tissue health in postmenopausal women, is not necessary for managing an asymptomatic, mild prolapse.

Key learning point: In asymptomatic cases of vaginal prolapse, conservative management and reassurance are appropriate, with surgical interventions reserved for symptomatic cases.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical estrogen is indicated for symptoms of vaginal atrophy, such as dryness and irritation, not for asymptomatic or mildly symptomatic prolapse. This patient does not report atrophic symptoms, and estrogen does not address the mechanical failure of pelvic support structures.
